inlineContent.text: This enum represents the Sun, Moon, planets, and select moons
that can be used in astronomical calculations.

abstract.text: A celestial body in the solar system.
Calculate the positions of celestial bodies in various coordinate systems.
Finds the next time this body rises above the horizon.
Jupiter.
Neptune.
The Earth-Moon Barycenter.
The Solar System Barycenter.
A geographic location for observing celestial objects.
Whether this body is a major planet.
The Galilean moons of Jupiter.
The Moon.
Pluto.
Returns all planetary apsides within a date range.
Searches for when this body reaches a specific altitude.
Internal star slot used by FixedStar.
Use the
type instead of accessing this directly.
The inner planets (Mercury, Venus, Mars).
Uranus.
Calculates the distance from the Sun to this body.
The outer planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune).
Europa, moon of Jupiter.
Calculates the heliocentric position of this body.
Searches for the next planetary apsis (perihelion or aphelion).
The human-readable name of this body.
Finds the next time this body sets below the horizon.
Searches for the time when this body reaches peak visual magnitude.
Calculates the elongation of this body at the specified time.
Searches for the next rise or set time.
Calculates the geocentric position of this body.
The orbital period around the Sun in days.
The Sun.
Saturn.
Transform positions between different astronomical coordinate systems.
Io, moon of Jupiter.
Calculates the equatorial coordinates of this body.
A celestial body in the solar system.
Whether this body is visible to the naked eye.
Callisto, moon of Jupiter.
Finds the next planetary apsis after a given apsis.
Searches for when this body reaches a specific hour angle.
The major planets (Mercury through Neptune).
Finds the next upper culmination (transit/meridian crossing).
Calculates the angular separation from the Sun.
Searches for the next maximum elongation of this body.
Venus.
Calculates the ecliptic longitude of this body.
Calculates the rotation axis orientation for this body at the specified time.
The Earth (for heliocentric calculations).
Calculates the horizontal coordinates for an observer.
Mars.
Ganymede, moon of Jupiter.
Calculates the illumination of this body at the specified time.
Swift bindings for Don Cross
library.
Finds which constellation this body is in at the specified time.
Calculate moon phases, quarters, libration, and lunar nodes.
The gravitational parameter (mass  G) in AU/day.
Mercury.
Creates a body from its name.
